meanings.definition: To soften the colors or outlines of (a painting or drawing) by covering them with a thin coat of opaque or semiopaque color.
meanings.sent1: She decided to scumble the harsh lines in her artwork to make it look more gentle.
meanings.sent2: Artists often scumble their paintings to create a dreamy effect.
meanings.sent3: The painter accidentally scumbled the colors, turning the landscape into a pastel wonderland.
meanings.sent4: Her emotions were like a storm, but she managed to scumble them into a peaceful sea on canvas.
meanings.sent5: With a delicate touch, she scumbled the edges, transforming the painting into a soft masterpiece.

meanings.definition: To soften the sharp outlines of (a drawing) by rubbing lightly.
meanings.sent1: He used a soft cloth to scumble the harsh lines of the sketch.
meanings.sent2: The artist gently scumbled the pencil marks to create a more blended effect.
meanings.sent3: As he scumbled the drawing, the lines seemed to dance and blur playfully.
meanings.sent4: Her memories were like sharp edges, but she scumbled them away with each stroke.
meanings.sent5: The sunlight filtered through the trees, creating a scumbled pattern on the forest floor.

meanings.definition: A thin, opaque coat of paint or layer of shading applied to a painting or drawing.
meanings.sent1: She added a scumble of white paint to highlight the edges of the portrait.
meanings.sent2: The artist used a scumble to create depth in the background of the painting.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous squirrel left a scumble of paw prints on the wet canvas.
meanings.sent4: The evening sky was a scumble of colors, blending into a peaceful twilight.
meanings.sent5: The old barn had a scumble of green moss growing on its weathered walls.
